articles.headline: Taliban Quash Protests and Seize Enemies, Tightening Grip on Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The Taliban’s actions and history of brutality cast doubt on their promises of amnesty, and many Afghans are afraid to venture out of their homes.
articles.abstract: The Taliban’s actions and history of brutality cast doubt on their promises of amnesty, and many Afghans are afraid to venture out of their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Taliban cracked down on protests that erupted in at least four cities in Afghanistan on Thursday and rounded up opponents despite promises of amnesty, even as fearful workers stayed home and thousands of people continued a frenzied rush to leave the country.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall, Marc Santora and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Hunted by the Taliban, U.S.-Allied Afghan Forces Are in Hiding
articles.snippet: The Afghan forces disintegrated ahead of the Taliban’s rapid advance. Now, the militants are searching for thousands of Afghan soldiers and security officials.
articles.abstract: The Afghan forces disintegrated ahead of the Taliban’s rapid advance. Now, the militants are searching for thousands of Afghan soldiers and security officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: Columns of Afghan soldiers in armored vehicles and pickup trucks sped through the desert to reach Iran. Military pilots flew low and fast to the safety of Uzbekistan’s mountains.

articles.headline: How News Organizations Got Afghan Colleagues Out of Kabul
articles.snippet: The evacuation of those who worked for outlets like The New York Times and The Washington Post came after a global rescue effort stretching from the Pentagon to Qatar.
articles.abstract: The evacuation of those who worked for outlets like The New York Times and The Washington Post came after a global rescue effort stretching from the Pentagon to Qatar.
articles.lead_paragraph: For hours, they waited on the tarmac in the relentless heat, children and suitcases and strollers in tow, hoping for a flight to freedom that would not come. More than 200 Afghans from all walks of life — cooks, gardeners, translators, drivers, journalists — gathered on the runway of the Kabul airport, seeking escape from a country whose government had collapsed with shocking speed.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum, Tiffany Hsu and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: As Chinese Vaccines Stumble, U.S. Finds New Opening in Asia
articles.snippet: Several Southeast Asian nations are raising doubts about the efficacy of China’s vaccines. The Biden administration has recently offered to provide shots, “no strings attached.”
articles.abstract: Several Southeast Asian nations are raising doubts about the efficacy of China’s vaccines. The Biden administration has recently offered to provide shots, “no strings attached.”
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — The arrival of the Chinese vaccines was supposed to help stop the spread of the coronavirus in Southeast Asia.
articles.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Who Gets the L.L.C.? Inside a Silicon Valley Billionaire’s Divorce.
articles.snippet: A couple are heading to court to decide who is entitled to a fortune, started in the earliest days of Google, that includes valuable California real estate and stock holdings.
articles.abstract: A couple are heading to court to decide who is entitled to a fortune, started in the earliest days of Google, that includes valuable California real estate and stock holdings.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — In 2014, Scott Hassan, known by some as the third Google founder, sent Allison Huynh, his wife of 13 years, a text message that their marriage was over and that he was moving out of their home.

articles.headline: Cutoff of Jobless Benefits Is Found to Get Few Back to Work
articles.snippet: Prematurely ending federal programs had little effect on employment but sharply cut spending, potentially hurting state economies, researchers say.
articles.abstract: Prematurely ending federal programs had little effect on employment but sharply cut spending, potentially hurting state economies, researchers say.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cutoff of federal unemployment benefits in much of the country was meant to bring a flood of workers back to the job market. So far, that flood looks more like a trickle.

articles.headline: Abrupt Exit of New ‘Jeopardy!’ Host, Mike Richards, Rattles a TV Institution
articles.snippet: Mr. Richards was named as Alex Trebek’s replacement last week, but offensive and sexist comments he made on a podcast several years ago resurfaced. He will remain as executive producer.
articles.abstract: Mr. Richards was named as Alex Trebek’s replacement last week, but offensive and sexist comments he made on a podcast several years ago resurfaced. He will remain as executive producer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Update, Aug. 31: Mike Richards is out as ‘Jeopardy!’ executive producer.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum, Nicole Sperling and Julia Jacobs

articles.headline: Tesla Sells ‘Full Self-Driving,’ but What Is It Really?
articles.snippet: As the company deals with government scrutiny of its driver-assistance technology, an add-on kit sold for up to $10,000 is also getting more attention.
articles.abstract: As the company deals with government scrutiny of its driver-assistance technology, an add-on kit sold for up to $10,000 is also getting more attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: As federal investigators escalate their scrutiny of Tesla’s driver-assistance technology, another problem is emerging for the electric carmaker: complaints among customers that they have been sold an additional driver-assistance option that doesn’t operate as advertised.
